summary: This is an email chain from July 2020 discussing a request from victims of Jeffrey Epstein for a formal victim notification letter from the FBI to assist with applications to a victim compensation fund. The correspondence involves law enforcement officials debating the legal and procedural challenges of issuing such letters, as not all interviewed individuals may qualify as victims of a federal crime.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the investigation; the perpetrator whose victims are seeking formal notification letters from the FBI.

connections.description: MI is a law enforcement official involved in the investigation of crimes committed by Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Request for Victim Notification Letters
events.description: A request was made by victims (or their representatives) for the FBI to provide formal victim notification letters to assist with applications to a victim compensation fund.

events.title: Scheduled Call to Discuss Victim Letters
events.description: A phone call was scheduled for the afternoon of Tuesday, July 28, 2020, among law enforcement officials to decide how to proceed with the victim notification letter request.

keyFacts: Victims of Jeffrey Epstein were seeking formal 'victim notification letters' from the FBI to use in applying for a victim compensation fund.
The FBI initially declined to provide FD-302 interview reports (standard interview forms) due to the active investigation.

Law enforcement officials acknowledged a legal complication: not all individuals they interviewed in the Epstein case were necessarily victims of a federal crime, which is what a standard notification letter would state.

The correspondence shows internal deliberation within the NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force about how to appropriately assist all individuals negatively affected by Epstein while adhering to legal protocols.
